'''Hip Linkchain''' (November 10, 1936 – February 13, 1989) was an [[United States|American]] [[Chicago blues]] guitarist, singer and songwriter.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p18799|pure_url=yes}}|title=Hip Linkchain |author=Bill Dahl |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref>

His best known numbers were "Change My Blues" and "That Will Never Do".<ref name="Dead">[http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1980.html Thedeadrockstarsclub.com] - accessed November 14, 2011</ref> [[Allmusic]] described him as a "solid, no-frills bluesman".<ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=airbusters-r188335|pure_url=yes}} |title=Allmusic ((( ''Airbusters'' > Overview )))}}</ref> Another [[music journalism|music journalist]] noted, "his composer's talents put him much above the average bluesmen".<ref name="Encyc">{{cite book
| first= Gérard
| last= Herzhaft
| year= 1997
| title= Encyclopedia of the blues
| edition= 2nd
| publisher= [[University of Arkansas Press]] 
| location= [[Fayetteville, Arkansas]], United States
| isbn= 1-55728-452-0
| page= 126}}</ref> Linkchain variously worked with [[Lester Davenport]], [[Pinetop Perkins]], [[Tyrone Davis]], and [[Little Walter]].<ref>{{cite book
| first= David Honeyboy
| last= Edwards
| year= 1997
| title= The World Don't Owe Me Nothing: The Life and Times of Delta Bluesman Honeyboy Edwards
| edition= 1st
| publisher= [[Independent Publishers Group|Chicago Review Press]] 
| location= Chicago, Illinois, United States
| isbn= 1-55652-368-8
| page= }}</ref>

==Life and career==
He was born '''Willie Richard''' in [[Jackson, Mississippi]], [[United States]]. His [[stage name]] was in deference to his father's nickname of 'Linkchain', due to his habit of sporting logging chains around his neck, and the boy's own childhood nickname of 'Hipstick'.<ref name="AMG"/><ref>{{cite book
| first= Adrian
| last= Room
| year= 1997
| title= Dictionary of Pseudonyms: 13,000 Assumed Names and Their Origins
| edition= 5th
| publisher= [[McFarland & Company]] 
| location= [[Jefferson, North Carolina]], United States
| isbn= 978-0-7864-4373-4
| page= 289}}</ref> He was inspired by the blues playing of [[Sonny Boy Williamson II]], [[Elmore James]] and [[Little Milton]], all of whom Linkchain heard in the [[Mississippi delta]], prior to him relocating to [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], in 1954.<ref name="AMG"/> He had been raised in [[Louise, Mississippi]], and picked cotton before his move north.<ref name="Teardrop">{{cite web |url=http://www.teardroprecords.com/linkchain.htm |title=''Change My Blues'' |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Teardroprecords.com |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref> Linkchain found regular employment playing blues guitar in the [[nightclub|clubs]] of Chicago throughout the 1950s and 1960s, and he variously worked with the harmonica players, [[Lester Davenport]], [[Dusty Brown (musician)|Dusty Brown]], and [[Willie Foster]].

By 1959, Linkchain had formed his own band known as the Chicago Twisters, who had [[Tyrone Davis]] as their [[frontman]]. Linkchain recorded spasmodically, mainly for small [[independent record label]]s based in Chicago, and a handful of his [[Single (music)|singles]] were released in the 1960s.  It was not until 1983 that Linkchain saw his debut [[album]] issued, when the small Teardrop Records outfit released ''Change My Blues''.<ref name="AMG"/> The recording saw Linkchain play alongside [[Pinetop Perkins]] (piano), Rich Kirch (guitar), Right Hand Frank Bandy (bass) and Fred Grady (drums).<ref name="Teardrop"/>

His best known album, ''Airbusters'', was originally released by the [[Netherlands]] based Black Magic record label in 1988.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://squeezemylemon.blogspot.com/2008/07/bluesman-you-probably-dont-know-hip.html |title=A bluesman you probably don't know: Hip Linkchain |author= |date=July 7, 2008 |work= |publisher=Squeezemylemon.blogpsot.com |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref> It was re-issued on the [[Evidence Records|Evidence]] label, but Linkchain was to experience only a short period of fame, before his death from [[cancer]] in Chicago in February 1989.<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Dead"/>
